findings.title: Potential zip-slip traversal strings present
findings.description: Archive-related code references traversal patterns like '../' or '..\'.
findings.risk: If used in archive entry names or extraction logic, traversal can overwrite or create files outside the intended directory.
findings.confidenceRationale: Traversal patterns are explicit; exact exploitability depends on the extraction implementation.
findings.recommendation: Reject any archive entries with traversal or absolute paths and enforce extraction under a fixed, canonical directory.

findings.title: Potential zip-slip traversal strings present

findings.title: Path traversal prevention may rely on regex-only sanitization
findings.description: Code appears to attempt path traversal prevention via string replace/regex logic.
findings.risk: Regex-only sanitization is commonly bypassed via encoding, separator tricks, and normalization edge cases.
findings.confidenceRationale: Heuristic: true safety requires canonicalization + base-directory enforcement.
findings.recommendation: Canonicalize paths (resolve/realpath) and enforce they remain within an expected base directory; avoid ad-hoc regex sanitization.

findings.title: Filename used without obvious sanitization
findings.description: Upload filename appears used without obvious normalization/sanitization nearby.
findings.risk: Unsanitized filenames can include traversal sequences, unicode tricks, or dangerous extensions.
findings.confidenceRationale: Heuristic: sanitization may exist in shared helpers; still worth review.
findings.recommendation: Normalize filenames, strip path separators, enforce allowlisted extensions, and generate server-side storage names.
